articles.headline: Israel’s Netanyahu Reopens Door to Palestinian State, but White House Is Unimpressed
articles.snippet: In his first interview since his re-election victory, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he had not intended to reverse his endorsement in a 2009 speech at Bar-Ilan University of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
articles.abstract: In his first interview since his re-election victory, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he had not intended to reverse his endorsement in a 2009 speech at Bar-Ilan University of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday tried to backtrack from his pre-election declaration that no Palestinian state would be established on his watch, but his new assertions appeared to do nothing to assuage an infuriated Obama administration.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Bar Exam, the Standard to Become a Lawyer, Comes Under Fire
articles.snippet: Many law school deans have begun to openly question the mechanics of the test, and some states are even exploring other options.
articles.abstract: Many law school deans have begun to openly question the mechanics of the test, and some states are even exploring other options.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, law school graduates have endured a stressful rite of passage, spending the first 10 weeks after classes end taking cram courses in the arcane details of the law before sitting down for the grueling, days-long bar exam. Those who do not pass cannot practice law, at least in nearly all the states and the District of Columbia that consider the exam the professional standard.

articles.headline: Elon Musk Says Self-Driving Tesla Cars Will Be in the U.S. by Summer
articles.snippet: The automaker’s chief executive says a software update will allow the Model S to navigate highways without the driver’s touching the wheel or pedals. But is it legal?
articles.abstract: The automaker’s chief executive says a software update will allow the Model S to navigate highways without the driver’s touching the wheel or pedals. But is it legal?
articles.lead_paragraph: For many drivers who commute long distances, the prospect of owning a self-driving car — where a driver takes his hands off the wheel and feet off the gas — has been an elusive dream.

articles.headline: Turning to Education for Fun
articles.snippet: People are turning to education for entertainment, whether from online lectures, learning vacations or television, for the love of learning new things and to stay economically viable.
articles.abstract: People are turning to education for entertainment, whether from online lectures, learning vacations or television, for the love of learning new things and to stay economically viable.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a 2013 episode of “60 Minutes,” Charlie Rose visits Bill Gates’s office to get a sense of where the billionaire philanthropist draws intellectual inspiration. First, Mr. Gates shows Mr. Rose the Codex Leicester, a 500-year-old Leonardo da Vinci manuscript that Mr. Gates bought in 1994 for $30 million.

articles.headline: In the Age of Information, Specializing to Survive
articles.snippet: As the amount of human-created information spirals ever higher, our ability to sift through it has not kept pace. Increasingly condensed specialization is one result.
articles.abstract: As the amount of human-created information spirals ever higher, our ability to sift through it has not kept pace. Increasingly condensed specialization is one result.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Haber majored in philosophy at Harvard University. And Yale. And Stanford. He explored Kant’s “The Critique of Pure Reason” with an Oxford don and Kierkegaard’s insights into “Subjectivity, Irony and the Crisis of Modernity” with a leading light from the University of Copenhagen.

articles.headline: Public Pension Cuts Exempt Police and Firefighters
articles.snippet: Recent labor legislation, such as measures to curb collective bargaining and change pensions and health coverage, often exempts public safety workers.
articles.abstract: Recent labor legislation, such as measures to curb collective bargaining and change pensions and health coverage, often exempts public safety workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Gov. Bruce Rauner of Illinois has traveled the state promoting his proposal for more than $2 billion in cuts to pensions for public employees. All public employees, that is, except police officers and firefighters.

articles.headline: Take Google to Court, Staff Report Urged F.T.C.
articles.snippet: An internal Federal Trade Commission report recommended that the agency take action against Google for anticompetitive practices. The F.T.C. voted not to bring charges.
articles.abstract: An internal Federal Trade Commission report recommended that the agency take action against Google for anticompetitive practices. The F.T.C. voted not to bring charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday faced renewed questions about its handling of its antitrust investigation into Google, after documents revealed that an internal report had recommended stronger action.
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: McConnell Urges States to Help Thwart Obama’s ‘War on Coal’
articles.snippet: Senator Mitch McConnell has begun an aggressive campaign to block President Obama’s climate agenda in statehouses and courtrooms, arenas far beyond his official authority.
articles.abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell has begun an aggressive campaign to block President Obama’s climate agenda in statehouses and courtrooms, arenas far beyond his official authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky has begun an aggressive campaign to block President Obama’s climate change agenda in statehouses and courtrooms across the country, arenas far beyond Mr. McConnell’s official reach and authority.

articles.headline: Israel Election Result Complicates Life for Clinton
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton could face resistance among polarized Jewish Democrats if she is critical of the Israeli leader.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton could face resistance among polarized Jewish Democrats if she is critical of the Israeli leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s victory in this week’s Israeli elections has reverberated through American politics, reinforcing Republican faith in the political wisdom of a hawkish foreign policy, worsening his relationship with President Obama, and energizing liberal critics of Israel’s government. But mostly it has complicated the life of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

articles.headline: At Kodak, Clinging to a Future Beyond Film
articles.snippet: What happens when a tech company is left for dead but the people left behind refuse to give up? At Kodak, the answer is to mine its patents for gold. (With video.)
articles.abstract: What happens when a tech company is left for dead but the people left behind refuse to give up? At Kodak, the answer is to mine its patents for gold. (With video.)
articles.lead_paragraph: Of the roughly 200 buildings that once stood on the 1,300-acre campus of Eastman Kodak’s business park in Rochester, 80 have been demolished and 59 others sold off. Terry Taber, bespectacled, 60, and a loyal Kodak employee of 34 years, still works in one of the remaining Kodak structures, rubble from demolition not far from its doors.

articles.headline: Biogen Reports Its Alzheimer’s Drug Sharply Slowed Cognitive Decline
articles.snippet: The drug, developed by Biogen Idec, could achieve sales of billions of dollars a year if the results from the small trial are replicated in larger trials.
articles.abstract: The drug, developed by Biogen Idec, could achieve sales of billions of dollars a year if the results from the small trial are replicated in larger trials.
articles.lead_paragraph: An experimental drug for Alzheimer’s disease sharply slowed the decline in mental function in a small clinical trial, researchers reported Friday, reviving hopes for an approach to therapy that until now has experienced repeated failures.

articles.headline: Suicide Attacks at Mosques in Yemen Kill More Than 130
articles.snippet: An affiliate of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attacks at two Zaydi Shiite mosques in Sana, the capital.
articles.abstract: An affiliate of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attacks at two Zaydi Shiite mosques in Sana, the capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — An affiliate of the Islamic State that had not previously carried out any major attacks claimed responsibility for coordinated suicide strikes on Zaydi Shiite mosques here that killed more than 130 people during Friday Prayer, bringing to Yemen the kind of deadly sectarian fighting that has ripped apart Syria and Iraq.
articles.byline: By Mohammed Ali Kalfood, Kareem Fahim and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Breast Milk Becomes a Commodity, With Mothers Caught Up in Debate
articles.snippet: Researchers say the milk is brimming with potential therapeutic agents, for babies and also possibly adults.
articles.abstract: Researchers say the milk is brimming with potential therapeutic agents, for babies and also possibly adults.
articles.lead_paragraph: CITY OF INDUSTRY, Calif. — When Gretty Amaya took an unpaid maternity leave five months ago, she started what she calls a part-time job to help pay the bills. Ms. Amaya, who lives in Miami, has made more than $2,000 so far by pumping breast milk and selling what is left over after feeding her baby daughter.
